forkee.name: python-for-data-and-media-communication
forkee.description: Sample codes and datasets for COMM7780/ JOUR7280 @ HKBU

issue.title: A question about the codes to extract article url in week5
issue.body:
For the example in week5 which extracts all article urls in http://initiumlab.com, all the tags including the article urls have been collected like below
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42831899/46424907-f83ddf80-c76c-11e8-82ea-7b64b22804a7.png)

Next, we need to get the strings after 'href' (e.g.'href="../blog/20170113-Sharing-With-Friends-Versus-Strangers/"'), and the codes are as below:
```
for my_url in my_urls:
    url ='{0}{1}'.format('http://initiumlab.com',my_url['href'][2:]) #format urls
        #print(url)
    article_urls.append(url)
article_urls

```
However, I do not quite understand what `my_url['href'][2:]` means here. 'my_url['href']' seems to be a function of finding the  value through the corresponding key in a dictionary, but 'my_url' is a list element.  [2:] seems to be a function of extracting part of words in string. I feel a little bit confused.

issue.title: An alternative way to calculate the break-even point of subscribed users to make profit in Example21 in Week3
issue.body:
The Example 21 in Week3 tutorial is helpful for us to learn how the For loop works. But I also find that the same result can be achieved with the While loop as well. Below are the codes that I write to share with you guys for reference and suggestions. You can also check the results in nbviewer [here](http://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/kaiwenxu94/hkbu-big-data-exercises-and-projects/blob/master/python%20exercises/week3/Calculate%20the%20break-even%20point%20of%20subscribed%20users%20to%20make%20profit.ipynb).

```
Fixed_Cost = 30000
Content_Cost = 70000
member_ff = 15
convert_rate = 0.1
ad_revenue_each_person = 1
subscribers=0
net_income=0.1*subscribers*member_ff+ad_revenue_each_person*subscribers-Fixed_Cost-Content_Cost
if net_income==0:
	print(subscribers)
else:
	while subscribers>=0:
		subscribers=subscribers+1
		if subscribers<50000:
			net_income=0.1*subscribers*member_ff+ad_revenue_each_person*subscribers-Fixed_Cost-Content_Cost
		else:
			net_income=0.1*subscribers*member_ff+ad_revenue_each_person*subscribers-Fixed_Cost-Content_Cost-0.1*(subscribers-50000)
		if net_income==0:
			break
print(subscribers)
```

comment.body: @FLYSTEPHEN Thank you! I also learned a lot from your codes!

issue.title: An alternative way to calculate the break-even point of subscribed users to make profit in Example21 in Week3
issue.body:
The Example 21 in Week3 tutorial is helpful for us to learn how the For loop works. But I also find that the same result can be achieved with the While loop as well. Below are the codes that I write to share with you guys for reference and suggestions. You can also check the results in nbviewer [here](http://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/kaiwenxu94/hkbu-big-data-exercises-and-projects/blob/master/python%20exercises/week3/Calculate%20the%20break-even%20point%20of%20subscribed%20users%20to%20make%20profit-checkpoint.ipynb).

```
Fixed_Cost = 30000
Content_Cost = 70000
member_ff = 15
convert_rate = 0.1
ad_revenue_each_person = 1
subscribers=0
net_income=0.1*subscribers*member_ff+ad_revenue_each_person*subscribers-Fixed_Cost-Content_Cost
if net_income==0:
	print(subscribers)
else:
	while subscribers>=0:
		subscribers=subscribers+1
		if subscribers<50000:
			net_income=0.1*subscribers*member_ff+ad_revenue_each_person*subscribers-Fixed_Cost-Content_Cost
		else:
			net_income=0.1*subscribers*member_ff+ad_revenue_each_person*subscribers-Fixed_Cost-Content_Cost-0.1*(subscribers-50000)
		if net_income==0:
			break
print(subscribers)
```

issue.title: Week 3 Feedback
issue.body:
1. The outputs in Example4 should contain no parentheses and no quotation marks.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42831899/45600051-0d0a3b80-ba29-11e8-9d33-df1227c51418.png)
Below is the right version:
	>>> x=4
	>>> y=6
	>>> print('x!=y:',x!=y)
	x!=y: True

2. Remember to add parentheses, and list2[1:5]means slicing list2 from index1 value to index5 value but does not include index5 value. Also, list2[:2] means slcing list2 from index0 value to index2 value but does not include index2 value.  We had better explain the rule of slicing lists more clearly. It confused me when I saw the outputs in the first place.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42831899/45600069-3dea7080-ba29-11e8-98a1-c276db3473c3.png)

3. Delete the command of the third line in example8.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42831899/45600074-4f337d00-ba29-11e8-9c0f-662758f44a23.png)

4. In Example10, there is no key named 'Frank' or its corresponding value. 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42831899/45600078-5fe3f300-ba29-11e8-938e-7e75a0dfa331.png)
If we try to access the value of a key that does not exist in the list, an error will be reported as follows:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42831899/45600080-64a8a700-ba29-11e8-9130-ecf65ac8599b.png)

5. In Example22, the last line（i=i+1）should only have one indentation, otherwise the output will be 1 endlessly and never breaks:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42831899/45600083-6f633c00-ba29-11e8-942f-1e00149e85a4.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42831899/45600096-96217280-ba29-11e8-85db-18db7a347478.png)
Below is the right version:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42831899/45600099-a20d3480-ba29-11e8-9223-4b1de659b6de.png)

6. In the first line, the input('please input a int:') will produce a string, and the type of a string is never equal to the type of 1. Hence, ValueError will be always raised if you put either 2 or 2.2. The 2 and 2.2 you input are strings. Therefore, you need to add a int() function before the input(), because int('2.2') leads to a ValueError while int('2') can produce an int.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42831899/45600102-b5b89b00-ba29-11e8-85eb-04037a35820b.png)
Also, in the last line, remember to add parenthesis: print (inputValue)
The right version should be:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42831899/45600104-c1a45d00-ba29-11e8-8e16-f49f18be3b54.png)

comment.body: @ChicoXYC I get your point, many thanks!

issue.title: Week 3 Feedback
issue.body:
1. The outputs in Example4 should contain no parentheses and no quotation marks.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42831899/45600051-0d0a3b80-ba29-11e8-9d33-df1227c51418.png)
Below is the right version:
	>>> x=4
	>>> y=6
	>>> print('x!=y:',x!=y)
	x!=y: True

2. Remember to add parentheses, and list2[1:5]means slicing list2 from index1 value to index5 value but does not include index5 value. Also, list2[:2] means slcing list2 from index0 value to index2 value but does not include index2 value.  We had better explain the rule of slicing lists more clearly. It confused me when I saw the outputs in the first place.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42831899/45600069-3dea7080-ba29-11e8-98a1-c276db3473c3.png)

3. Delete the command of the third line in example8.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42831899/45600074-4f337d00-ba29-11e8-9c0f-662758f44a23.png)

4. In Example10, there is no key named 'Frank' or its corresponding value. 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42831899/45600078-5fe3f300-ba29-11e8-938e-7e75a0dfa331.png)
If we try to access the value of a key that does not exist in the list, an error will be reported as follows:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42831899/45600080-64a8a700-ba29-11e8-9130-ecf65ac8599b.png)

5. In Example22, the last line（i=i+1）should only have one indentation, otherwise the output will be 1 endlessly and never breaks:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42831899/45600083-6f633c00-ba29-11e8-942f-1e00149e85a4.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42831899/45600096-96217280-ba29-11e8-85db-18db7a347478.png)
Below is the right version:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42831899/45600099-a20d3480-ba29-11e8-9223-4b1de659b6de.png)

6. In the first line, the input('please input a int:') will produce a string, and the type of a string is never equal to the type of 1. Hence, ValueError will be always raised if you put either 2 or 2.2. The 2 and 2.2 you input are strings. Therefore, you need to add a int() function before the input(), because int('2.2') leads to a ValueError while int('2') can produce an int.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42831899/45600102-b5b89b00-ba29-11e8-85eb-04037a35820b.png)
Also, in the last line, remember to add parenthesis: print (inputValue)
The right version should be:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42831899/45600104-c1a45d00-ba29-11e8-8e16-f49f18be3b54.png)
